bibl.title: Letter from Howard A. Kelly to Juan Guiteras, October 26, 1907

div1.p: Kelly requests permission to publish a letter from Carroll stating that Guiteras refused permission to take blood for the yellow fever experiments. Guiteras responds - in a autograph note on the same document - that he had no authority to permit or prevent Carroll from proceeding as he wished.

div1.head: Letter from Howard A. Kelly to Juan Guiteras, October 26, 1907
div1.opener:
Dr L
Keep with his
writings
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
1418 EUTAW PLACE Oct. 26, 1907.
Dear Dr. Guiteras,--
div1.p:
Dr. Carroll, as you
know, has died, and we have recently held
a Memorial meeting at the Hospital, at
which I read an account of his life. In
a letter written by him, he states that he
was not able to get blood to test the con-
tagiousness of the disease, on his return
to the Las Ensinas Hospital, because you ob-
jected, and that you were sustained in your
objection by Major Ross.

I write to ask if you have any ob-
jection to Dr. Carroll's letter appearing
in the little life which I will publish
in the Bulletin.

I write to you because of my long-
standing friendship and high regard for you
and your work, & because I would not on any
account hurt your feelings. I believe
it is more than likely that the matter is
one to which you would not pay any atten-
tion.

Always sincerely yours,
Howard A. Kelly,
K.

Dear Dr. Kelly
this letter comes to
me with an under ununderstandable
one from Ramon Guiteras. I suppose
he had gotten your letter to me by
mistake.
Dr. Carroll was quite nervous at
the time and inclined to believe easily

that every body was putting obstacles
in his way.

on his second visit to Las Animas
Dr. Carroll did not have to test
the contagiousness of the disease.
Together with Reed and Agramonte
he had proven the transmissibility
of the disease at the time of their
former visit.

I thought during this second
visit that I had done all that
I could to help him in his
work. I was not in command
at Las Animas Hospital, nor
in the Health Department at that
time, and had no authority to
either prevent or permit his
taking blood.
